FacilityName: Hydro Agri North America, Inc. (Ammonia Terminal)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
                                                               EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
                                                          Hydro Agri North America, Inc.
                                                             Tampa Ammonia Terminal

TAMPA FACILITY:

Hydro Agri North America, Inc. Is a corporation wholly owned by Norsk Hydro ASA, a global company with headquarters in Brussells, Belgium, and engaged in the production and shipping of ammonia, fertilizer, oil and gas, and specialty metals.

Hydro Agri North America, Inc. purchased the Tampa Ammonia Terminal, in its entirety, from the limited partnership corporation formerly known as Farmland Hydro, L.P. In November, 2002. The facility is located about 1 mile west of U.S. Route 41 on Port Sutton Road and south of Tampa, Florida.The facility receives anhydrous ammonia from ocean-going vessels, stores the ammonia at near atmospheric pressure, and transfers the ammonia to its customers via a pipeline (primarily) and trucks. The facility is situated on Port Sutton Channel, with dock facilities for one ship, and storage tanks with the capacity for up to 49,000 tons of ammonia.The ammonia is in liquid form and is maintained at low temperature (-28? F) to keep the storage tank pressure below one pound per square inch.

POLLUTION PREVENTION POLICY:

Hydro Agri North America, Inc. is committed to protecting the environment and preserving our natural resources for future generations. We strive to eliminate or reduce our use of toxic substances and to minimize our use of energy and the generation of all wastes to the extent technically and economically feasible. We strive to minimize the generation of pollution at the source, but, where that cannot be achieved, we are committed to environmentally sound methods of recycling, treatment, and disposal. By preventing pollution at the source, we strive to achieve cost savings, increase

operational efficiencies, and maintain a safe and healthy workplace.

REGULATED SUBSTANCE:

Anhydrous Ammonia is the only regulated substance at this facility subject to EPA Risk Management Program and the OSHA Process Safety Management Program. The Tampa Ammonia Terminal receives all of its ammonia via ships and transfers the ammonia out of the facility via a pipeline (owned by others) and tank trucks. The ammonia contains a small amount (0.20-0.50%) of water which serves as a corrosion inhibitor.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY:

The management and employees of this facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases. It is the personal challenge and policy of the management and associates of this facility to identify and reduce or eliminate all recognized process hazards.

To reduce or eliminate accidents and prevent accidental releases, the facility is committed to the following:

* A knowledgeable, highly trained, and motivated employee group.
* A well-designed facility that is state-of-the-art and that is maintained and operated in a superior manner.
* Improvements that enhance safety and accident prevention.
* Preparation and training for emergency response.

Hydro Agri North America, Inc. has always had a written Emergency Response Plan in effect, and all of its employees are trained to the extent of First Responder level for ammonia release emergencies. The plan is designed to prevent employee exposure and to coordinate with local emergency response agencies in the event of a release. A shared community and plant emergency siren system is in operation and tested on a monthly basis. This plan is coordinated with the local community response plan, and is available to those responding agencies. Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information, as required under SARA Title III, has been provided to the State Emergency Response Commission, the Local Emergency Planning Committee, and the local fire departmen

t.

PREVENTION PROGRAM:

The Tampa Terminal is subject to OSHA Process Safety Management Rule, and is therefore under the EPA Risk Management Rule. It is a Program 3 facility with a Program 3 Prevention Program. The OSHA PSM/EPA Prevention Program consists of a set of facility management policies and procedures which promote and recognize process safety and the prevention of accidents in plants that handle, use, store, and process hazardous chemicals above the threshold quantity specified. The procedures address all aspects of plant activities, including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, safe work practices, incident investigation, audits, and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures, and inadvertent changes in a process which could result in accidents.

The prevention program consists of many elements and policies, which are briefly outlined below.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION: Employees participate in all aspects of the program, and are provided with the information developed in the program.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION: All necessary process information and records are maintained in several convenient locations, including information on the hazards of the chemicals, process technology with safe operating limits, and equipment records and design requirements.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS: Contract employees, with extensive professional training in the methods of process hazard analysis (PHA), are retained to act as PHA team leaders and work in conjunction with the Terminal employees. These reviews are updated on a regular basis.

OPERATING PROCEDURES: Operating procedures are in place for all aspects of the operation, including emergency operation and shutdown.

OPERATIONS TRAINING: All operators receive initial training in the process and its operating procedures and are supervised by an experienced operator for a lengthy training period before being allowed to control the process on their own. They must pass

written exams and demonstrate competency in all aspects of plant operation, including unexpected malfunctions.

CONTRACTORS: Contractor selection includes review of safety performance and programs. All contractor employees are required to attend an initial 16 hour OSHA/MSHA structured class offered at several local community training facilities. Contractors are also required to have had recent site-specific training from the facility. Periodic evaluations are made to assure that work is completed in a safe manner.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW: A safety review is conducted on any new process equipment or any significant modification of the process. This assures that construction and equipment installed are in accordance with design, that all necessary procedures, including safety procedures, are in place, that necessary training is completed, and that hazard analysis or other requirements of management of change are completed.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY: This is a quality assurance procedure to assure that equipment, parts, materials, and installations are suitable for the applications intended. Maintenance employees are trained in process hazards and safety procedures applicable to their work. Inspections, procedures, and testing are conducted under this part of the program.

SAFE WORK PRACTICES: Procedures and policies for all work permits and maintenance lockout/tagout
procedures are in force, and are periodically reviewed for completeness and effectiveness.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE: No changes in the process or procedures are allowed without a review and authorization. Safety impacts, technical review, required procedure modifications, and training needed are all considered in this review.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION: Any accident, near-miss, or incident that resulted in, or could have resulted in, an ammonia release is promptly investigated by a facility team. Findings of the investigation team and their recommendations for corrective action are documented, as is the resolution of t

ds, resulted in no deaths, no injuries, no property or environmental damage, but required approximately 300 off-site personnel to shelter in place briefly.  

SYNOPSIS OF WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The Risk Management rule requires a hazard analysis for worst case and alternate case accidental release scenarios for regulated substances. The rule requires an analysis involving the release of the total contents of the largest storage vessel of ammonia at this site. This is called the "worst case toxic release scenario" (worst case scenario) and involves the release of 32,250 tons of ammonia. This release must be considered to occur over a 10- minute period and pooling of the ammonia can be considered when modeling this release. We have retained a consultant to model this unlikely release utilizing a model known as DEGADOSE. His modeling results, according to the rule, determined that there would be off-site impacts. This worst case is a requirement of the rule, regardless of whether the event is likely, or if it could even reasonably occur. 

An alternate scenario, which is a more likely event, is required to be submitted. The alternate case chosen involved the release of ammonia from a transfer pipe where 96,000 pounds would be released over a 2 minute period. A significantly lower quantity is involved because various shutdown safeguards have been installed and operator intervention will tend to mitigate and limit the quantity in such cases. The same modeling techniques were applied and resulted in much lesser off-site impact.

PLANNED CHANGES FOR SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS: 

Safety improvements are a continual and ongoing process at the Tampa Ammonia Terminal facility. This process is facilitated by the Prevention Program/Process Safety Management Program. Many process safeguards have been implemented as a result of the Process Hazard Analysis and the Incident Investigation activities. The increased emphasis on security measures since September 11, 2001

he recommendations and corrective actions.

COMPLIANCE AUDIT: The program is audited at least every three years to verify compliance with these procedures. Findings of the audit are documented and any deficiencies are corrected and documented.

5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: 

The Risk Management rule requires inclusion of the 5-year accident history of the facility for all accidental releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or any known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. Under these criteria, there have been three release incidents in the facility's last five years, although only one was of the Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds. These three incidents are reported in Section 6 of this submission and are summarized below.

* April 1, 2002 at 1:45 p.m., duration of 5 minutes, vapor release from the 33K Storage Tank vacuum/vent valve, caused by warm ammonia from a discharging vessel creating a tank pressure spike and with human error contributing (poor communication with ship), estimated release of 1,300 pounds, resulted in no deaths, 16 first aid cases off-site, no property or environmental damage.

* February 4, 2003 at 4:00 p.m., duration of less than one minute, vapor release from a safety valve on the inlet piping to the CP Condenser, caused by over-pressurization due to a combination of human error (failure to open valve to the Receiver) and mechanical failure (alarm switch failed due to bad wiring), estimated release of 25 pounds, resulted in no deaths, no injuries, no property or environmental damage, but required approximately 300 off-site personnel to shelter in place briefly.

* March 5, 2003 at 11:00 a.m., duration of 10 minutes, liquid release vaporizing to the air from a pump seal, caused by gas pocket in pump causing false 0 pressure reading and human error (mechanic loosened seal without first purging pump with nitrogen), estimated release of 60 poun

has also been instrumental in many improvements, such as an expanded video surveillance system, improved fencing, all electronically controlled gates, intruder alarms, crash barriers, and greatly enhanced lighting. Among the many improvements currently scheduled for this facility within the next year or two are even more security cameras, more radios, more ammonia sensors, an improved ship/shore emergency shutdown device, installation of quantifier/alarm systems on all Storage Tank vacuum/vent valves, the installation of a deluge vapor suppression system, upgrading of instrumentation, upgrading of compressor systems, the testing/repairing/painting/re-insulating of Terminal piping, and the institution of a Preventive Maintenance Program. It is the belief of Hydro Agri North America, Inc. that through improvements like these and the diligent application of the elements of the Prevention Program/Process Safety Management Program that our employees and the community can be assured that the need for emergency response has been, and will continue to be, significantly diminished and hopefully will never be necessary.
